M1A.name: Dry Mead
M1A.overall_impression: Similar in balance, body, finish and flavor intensity to a dry white wine, with a pleasant mixture of subtle honey character, soft fruity esters, and clean alcohol. Complexity, harmony, and balance of sensory elements are most desirable, with no inconsistencies in color, aroma, flavor or aftertaste. The proper balance of sweetness, acidity, alcohol, and honey character is the essential final measure of any mead.
M1A.aroma: Honey aroma may be subtle, although not always identifiable. Sweetness or significant honey aromatics should not be expected. If a honey variety is declared, the variety should be distinctive (if noticeable). Different types of honey have different intensities and characters. Standard description applies for remainder of characteristics.
M1A.mouthfeel: Standard description applies, although the body is generally medium to light (but not watery). Note that stronger meads can have a fuller body. Sensations of body should not be accompanied by noticeable residual sweetness.
M1A.characteristic_ingredients: Standard description applies. Traditional mead is made from honey, water, and yeast; no other ingredients are allowed.
M1A.style_comparison: See Introduction to Mead Guidelines for comparison of categories. May be entered as a traditional mead, cyser, pyment, or melomel. Generally a basic mead, but can be made with specialty honeys. Compared to a semi-sweet mead, a dry mead lacks sweetness and often has a sharper finish. Compared to a sweet mead, a dry mead will seem thinner in body and often more acidic.
commercial_examples: Rabbit's Foot Napa Valley Orange Blossom Dry Mead

M1B.name: Semi-Sweet Mead
M1B.overall_impression: Similar in balance, body, finish and flavor intensity to a semi-dry/off-dry white wine, with a pleasant mixture of honey character, soft fruity esters, and clean alcohol. Complexity, harmony, and balance of sensory elements are most desirable, with no inconsistencies in color, aroma, flavor or aftertaste. The proper balance of sweetness, acidity, alcohol, and honey character is the essential final measure of any mead.
M1B.aroma: Honey aroma should be noticeable, and can have a light sweetness that may express the aroma of flower nectar. If a variety of honey is declared, the aroma might have a subtle to very noticeable varietal character reflective of the honey (different varieties have different intensities and characters). Standard description applies for remainder of characteristics.
M1B.mouthfeel: Standard description applies, although the body is generally medium-light to medium-full. Note that stronger meads will have a fuller body. Sensations of body should not be accompanied by a residual sweetness that is higher than moderate.
M1B.characteristic_ingredients: Standard description applies. Traditional mead is made from honey, water, and yeast; no other ingredients are allowed.
M1B.style_comparison: See Introduction to Mead Guidelines for comparison of categories. May be entered as a traditional mead, cyser, pyment, or melomel. Generally a basic mead, but can be made with specialty honeys. Compared to a dry mead, a semi-sweet mead is sweeter and more full-bodied. Compared to a sweet mead, a semi-sweet mead will be less sweet and have less body.

M1C.name: Sweet Mead
M1C.overall_impression: Similar in balance, body, finish and flavor intensity to a well-made dessert wine (such as Sauternes), with a pleasant mixture of honey character, residual sweetness, soft fruity esters, and clean alcohol. Complexity, harmony, and balance of sensory elements are most desirable, with no inconsistencies in color, aroma, flavor or aftertaste. The proper balance of sweetness, acidity, alcohol, and honey character is the essential final measure of any mead.
M1C.aroma: Honey aroma should be pronounced, and can have a moderate to strong sweetness that may express the aroma of flower nectar. If a variety of honey is declared, the aroma might have a subtle to very noticeable varietal character reflective of the honey (different varieties have different intensities and characters). Standard description applies for remainder of characteristics.
M1C.mouthfeel: Standard description applies, although the body is generally medium-full to full. Note that stronger meads will have a fuller body. Many seem like a dessert wine. Sensations of body should be accompanied by a complementary residual sweetness.
M1C.characteristic_ingredients: Standard description applies. Traditional mead is made from honey, water, and yeast; no other ingredients are allowed.
M1C.style_comparison: See Introduction to Mead Guidelines for comparison of categories. May be entered as a traditional mead, cyser, pyment, or melomel. Generally a basic mead, but can be made with specialty honeys. Compared to a semi-sweet mead, a sweet mead is sweeter and more full-bodied. Similar in sweetness and body to a sack mead.

M2A.name: Cyser
M2A.overall_impression: In well-made examples, the fruit is both distinctive and well-incorporated into the honey-sweet-acid-tannin-alcohol balance of the mead. Some of the best strong examples have the taste and aroma of an aged Calvados (apple brandy from northern France), while subtle, dry versions can taste similar to many fine white wines.
M2A.appearance: Standard description applies, except perhaps the color. Color may range from pale straw to deep golden-amber (most are yellow to gold), depending on the variety of honey and blend of apples or ciders used.
M2A.aroma: Depending on the sweetness and strength, a subtle to distinctly identifiable honey and apple/cider character (dry and/or hydromel versions will tend to have lower aromatics than sweet and/or sack versions). The apple/cider character should be clean and distinctive; it can express a range of apple-based character ranging from a subtle fruitiness to a single varietal apple character (if declared) to a complex blend of apple orchard character. Some spicy or earthy notes may be present, as may a slightly sulfury character (both are optional). Standard description applies for remainder of characteristics.
M2A.mouthfeel: Standard description applies. Often wine-like. Some natural acidity is usually present (from the apples) and helps balance the overall impression. Astringency from apple tannins is optional but should not be excessive.
M2A.comments: Cyser (SIGH-zer) may be made with the addition of apples or apple juice to honey, or by the addition of honey to apple juice or cider. A spiced cyser, or a cyser with other fruit, should be entered as an Experimental Mead. A cyser with a berry is a berry mead.
M2A.characteristic_ingredients: Standard description applies. Cyser is a mead made with the addition of apples or apple juice. Traditionally, cysers are made by the addition of honey to apple juice or apple cider.
M2A.style_comparison: Depending on the declared sweetness and strength level, a cyser may be similar to a white wine, apple wine, or cider. Compared to a standard mead, a cyser will have increased acidity and apple character. Compared to a braggot, a cyser will be fruitier and less malty (obviously).
